node.title: For Knicks, Success (and Failure) Arrives 3 Points at a Time
node.alt: Julius Randle made all four of his 3-pointers in the first quarter on Monday.
node.description: A devotion to long-distance shots has changed the Knicksâ€™ approach and their results. But is trading 3s for 3s a winning strategy?
node.content: ["Near the end of the first quarter on Monday, Julius Randle, the Knicks\u2019 burly All-Star forward, pulled up and banked in a shot from 25 feet. It was the kind of shot that might have sent him to the bench in a previous era of basketball, or even on a previous Tom Thibodeau-coached team. On Monday, it was Randle\u2019s fourth 3-pointer in 12 minutes.", "It was also a shot emblematic of the new-look Knicks: This year\u2019s version is taking 3-pointers. Lots of them. In the first quarter alone against the Toronto Raptors on Monday, 13 of the Knicks\u2019 19 shots \u2014 and five of Randle\u2019s \u2014 were from behind the 3-point line. The approach has been a hallmark of the new Bing Bong era of the Knicks, and it is part of the reason Thibodeau\u2019s team is off to a 5-2 start, the franchise\u2019s best since the 2012-13 season.", "In their second game, the Knicks set a team record for most 3-point field goals in a game with 24, on the way to a 121-96 victory. This year, the Knicks are taking 40.6 deep shots per game; that is good for eighth in the N.B.A. and 10 more per game than last season, when the Knicks ranked near the bottom of the league in attempts.", "\u201cWith the 3, you can make up ground quickly,\u201d Thibodeau said. Or not. On Monday, the Knicks tried 38 of them, but didn\u2019t make enough of them and absorbed their second defeat of the season, a 113-104 loss to the Raptors.", "While the Knicks didn\u2019t try as many 3s last season, they were accurate in the ones they shot: 39.2 percent overall, good for third in the N.B.A. This year, they are near the top in accuracy again, only with more volume. At their current rate, the Knicks are on track to have a top-five offense for the first time since that 2012-13 team.", "The Knicks have also picked up their pace, if only slightly. Last season, the Knicks were dead last in fast-break points. This year, they are 22nd.", "\u201cI think this is the fastest I\u2019ve seen them play for a long time,\u201d Toronto Coach Nick Nurse said before Monday\u2019s game.", "The early positive returns on the Knicks\u2019 season are the clearest indication that Thibodeau \u2014 a coach known for stubborn adherence to his brand of physical basketball \u2014 is capable of adjusting to the new realities of the modern N.B.A. He has reinvented the team\u2019s offensive identity with a simple mantra.", "\u201cDrive the ball, get your spacing, make your rim read \u2014 keep the game simple,\u201d Thibodeau told reporters on Monday, adding, \u201cWhen we do that, we\u2019re really good.\u201d", "Still, the transition to a more 3-pointer-heavy offense wasn\u2019t simply a case of telling the team to shoot more of them.", "Thibodeau received a significant assist \u2014 or by some interpretations, had his hand forced \u2014 by a shift in personnel. Last season, the Knicks\u2019 starting point guard was Elfrid Payton, a nonshooter whom opposing defenses would often ignore on the perimeter, clogging the paint for Randle and leaving him more susceptible to double teams. This year, Kemba Walker has occupied that spot, and he entered Monday night shooting an almost assuredly unsustainable 57.9 percent on 3-pointers.", "It is not just having better shooters. Walker and Evan Fournier are superior ballhandlers, and their arrival, along with the improved RJ Barrett, allows the Knicks to more easily break down defenses and create open opportunities on the outside.", "Having a healthy Mitchell Robinson in the starting lineup has been a boost as well. At 7 feet, Robinson draws attention at the rim as one of the Knicks\u2019 best alley-oop threats at the basket. That gives the Knicks more space on the perimeter to create open looks.", "If there is a worrisome sign, it is on the defensive end, where the Knicks have been below average \u2014 something highly unusual for a Thibodeau-coached team. While the Knicks have been taking a lot of 3s, they also give up a lot \u2014 more than all but two teams in the N.B.A.", "Their new acquisitions \u2014 Walker and Fournier \u2014 aren\u2019t known for their defense. On Monday, the Knicks surrendered looks \u2014 and points \u2014 on the inside and outside to Raptors forward OG Anunoby, who scored 36 points. While Toronto made only 14 of its 42 3-point shots, it was enough to pad a double-digit lead in the second half.", "Seven games isn\u2019t a huge sample size. Inevitably, some shooting numbers, like Walker\u2019s, will return to earth. But the new-look Knicks, with a sleek, contemporary offense, seem to have the personnel to merit their early optimism."]
